name: mirounga-angustirostris
definition: The northern elephant seal  is one of two species of elephant seal .
description:
Northern elephant seals are generally brown in color, however there are variations to this coloration.

The most conspicuous feature to the male body is the inflated proboscis that adorns his face.

This feature is absent in females and is larger than that of their slightly larger close relatives, southern elephant seals.

These mammals are among the largest of the group comprising aquatic carnivores in the Northern Hemisphere.

Females typically weigh 600 to 900 kilograms and males, which outweigh females by 3 to 10 times, can top out at 2300 kilograms.

Females reach a length of 3.1 meters on average and males usually extend from 4 to 5 meters.

Teeth are dimorphic in the sexes, with males having considerably enlarged canines that are used in fighting.

These mammals can dive exceptionally deep, usually 500 to 600 meters with record of over 1500 meters, for extended periods of time - between 20 and 70 minutes.

Northern elephant seals are found in the coastal waters of the Pacific Ocean from the Gulf of Alaska down to Baja California.

Northern elephant seals reside terrestrially on the sandy, rocky or muddy shores of the coastline, particularly on offshore islands.

These animals spend only 10% of their time on land, during reproduction and moulting.

The other 90% is spent in the water, diving and foraging for food, and only 11% of this time in the water is spent at the surface.

This means that an extraordinary 85 to 90% of their time is spent at sea and under water.

Females and males feed separately from each other.

Males are more likely to eat food sources that are dense in mass such as sharks and skates, while females eat foods that are less dense such as squid.

While elephant seals are on land they are fasting.

Foods eaten include cephalopods, skates, small sharks, and fish.

Northern elephant seals try to feed by diving deep when in the water because the animals that view them as prey typically feed near the surface.

Females migrate to the open ocean to feed in order to avoid predators as much as possible.

Northern elephant seals mating system is highly polygynous; a successful male is able to impregnate up to 50 females in one season.

These animals display a phenomenon in their development cycle called delayed implantation.

Delayed implantation lasts for about 3 months, resulting in a total gestation time of nearly one year.

Usually a single pup is born, although there have been occurrences of twins, and lactation will follow for about 27 days before the pup is weaned.

Pup weight gain during the period of lactation is phenomenal, the milk being extremely high in fat.

They typically aggregate in large groups while on land.

During their foraging migrations, they dive into the water repeatedly and continuously to find food, never stopping to rest or sleep for months at a time.

The male’s proboscis is used to produce extremely loud roaring noises, particularly during the mating season.

related.definition: The southern elephant seal  is one of the two species of elephant seals.
The leopard seal is the second largest species of seal in the Antarctic.
The South American sea lion is a sea lion found on the coasts of South America.
The California sea lion  is a coastal eared seal native to western North America.
The walrus  is a large flippered marine mammal with a discontinuous distribution about the North Pole in the Arctic Ocean and subarctic seas of the Northern Hemisphere.
The crabeater seal s a true seal with a circumpolar distribution around the coast of Antarctica.
